p: Despite research demonstrating the effects of heat on pregnant women, the effects of heat on them and their fetuses have often been left out of this discussion. The more recent assessment by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change did explore the adverse effects of heat on maternal health outcomes [ 10]. The World Health Organization has named improving maternal and child health a continued focus in their Sustainable Development Goals, as targets from the Millennium Development Goals for maternal and child health were met. Despite improvements in reducing under age five child mortality and the global maternal mortality ratio, both efforts failed to meet the respective 66% and 75% reduction goals [ 11]. Up to 40.3% of deaths in children under five years of age occur in neonates [ 12], and preterm births account for 35% of neonatal mortality worldwide [ 1]. Preterm birth rates may reach 18% in some sub-Saharan African and South Asian countries, and only three countries globally successfully reduced preterm birth rates from 1990 to 2010 [ 1].
